Herein, taking Na"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"3.5"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"V"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"1.5"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"Mn"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"0.5"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"(PO"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"4"},{"#name":"__text__","_":")"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"3"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" (NVMP) as an example, a reinforced concrete-like hierarchical and porous hybrid (NVMP@C@3DPG) built from 3D graphene (“rebar”) frameworks and "},{"#name":"italic","_":"in situ"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" generated carbon coated NVMP (“concrete”) has been developed by a facile polymer assisted self-assembly and subsequent solid-state method. Such hybrids deliver superior rate capability (73.9 mAh/g up to 20 C) and excellent cycling stability in a wide temperature range with a high specific capacity of 88.4 mAh/g after 5000 cycles at 15 C at room temperature, and a high capacity retention of 97.1% after 500 cycles at 1 C (−20 °C), and maintaining a high reversible capacity of 110.3 mAh/g in full cell. class=\"key-dates-help\"><h3 class=\"u-margin-s-bottom u-h4\">Publication milestones</h3><p class=\"u-margin-m-bottom\">The dates displayed for an article provide information on when various publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. View our <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/researcher/author/submit-your-paper\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing with Elsevier: step-by-step</span></span></a> page to learn more about the publishing process. class="PageDivider"></div></div></div></div><article class="col-lg-12 col-md-16 pad-left pad-right u-padding-s-top" lang="en"><div class="Publication" id="publication"><div class="publication-brand class="publication-volume u-text-center"><h2 class="publication-title u-h3" id="publication-title"><a class="anchor anchor-secondary publication-title-link" href="/journal/chinese-chemical-letters" class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/journal/chinese-chemical-letters/vol/35/issue/4" title="Go to table of contents for this volume/issue"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Volume 35, Issue 4</span></span></a>, <!-- -->April 2024<!-- -->, 109267</div></div><div class="publication-cover u-display-block-from-sm"><a class="anchor u-display-flex class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cclet.2023.109267" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cclet.2023.109267</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author" id="abs0001"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abss0001"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara005"><span><span>Realizing high-rate capability and high-efficiency utilization of polyanionic <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode materials</a><span> is of great importance for practical sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) since they usually suffer from extremely low <a href="/topics/engineering/electronic-conductivity" title="Learn more about electronic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic conductivity</a> and limited </span></span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/ionic-diffusion" title="Learn more about ionic diffusion from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic diffusion</a> kinetics. Herein, taking Na</span><sub>3.5</sub>V<sub>1.5</sub>Mn<sub>0.5</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span> (NVMP) as an example, a reinforced concrete-like hierarchical and porous hybrid (NVMP@C@3DPG) built from <a href="/topics/engineering/3d-graphene" title="Learn more about 3D graphene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">3D graphene</a> (“rebar”) frameworks and </span><em>in situ</em><span> generated carbon coated NVMP (“concrete”) has been developed by a facile polymer assisted self-assembly and subsequent solid-state method. Such hybrids deliver superior rate capability (73.9 mAh/g up to 20 C) and excellent cycling stability in a wide temperature range with a high specific capacity of 88.4 mAh/g after 5000 cycles at 15 C at <a href="/topics/chemistry/ambient-reaction-temperature" title="Learn more about room temperature from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">room temperature</a>, and a high capacity retention of 97.1% after 500 cycles at 1 C (−20 °C), and maintaining a high reversible capacity of 110.3 mAh/g in full cell. This work offers a facile and efficient strategy to develop advanced polyanionic cathodes with high-efficiency utilization and 3D electron/ion transport systems.</span></div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="abs0002"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="abss0002"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara006">Reinforced concrete-like Na<sub>3.5</sub>V<sub>1.5</sub>Mn<sub>0.5</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>@graphene hybrids with hierarchical porosity have been rationally designed. Such hybrids efficiently integrate high electronic conductivity, high ionic transport and robust mechanical strengthen, thus enabling superior rate capability and cycling performance in a wide temperature range.<span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-ga1.jpg" height="241" alt="Image, graphical abstract"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (314KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (314KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S1001841723006897"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S1001841723006691"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="keys0001" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="key0001" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0002">Sodium-ion battery</span></div><div id="key0002" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0003">Polyanionic cathode</span></div><div id="key0003" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0004">Hybrid structure</span></div><div id="key0004" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0005">Interconnected structure</span></div><div id="key0005" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0006">Energy storage</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0001"><span>Sodium-ion battery (SIB) has become one of the most promising alternatives to lithium-ion battery (LIB) owing to earth-abundance, widespread availability, and low cost of <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> resources </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0001" name="bbib0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0002" name="bbib0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0003" name="bbib0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a><span><span>. Currently, enormous efforts have been dedicated to developing high-performance <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode materials</a> since the breakthroughs for SIBs rely primarily on cathodes in terms of the working voltage, </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a><span>, cell cost and safety. Among various exploited cathode, <a href="/topics/food-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about superionic conductor from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">superionic conductor</a> (NASICON)-type polyanionic materials have been considered as one of the most promising cathode candidates for SIBs due to the facilitated Na</span></span></span><sup>+</sup><span><span> <a href="/topics/chemistry/ion-mobility" title="Learn more about ion mobility from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ion mobility</a> and high </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> endowed by 3D open framework structure </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0004" name="bbib0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>. As a typical representative, Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP) has been extensively studied and exhibits decent Na<sup>+</sup> storage capacity and superior cycling stability <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0005" name="bbib0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a><span>. Such phosphates, however, still suffer from poor <a href="/topics/engineering/electronic-conductivity" title="Learn more about electronic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic conductivity</a> and sluggish Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-kinetics" title="Learn more about diffusion kinetics from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion kinetics</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0006" name="bbib0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, thereby deteriorating rate performance. In addition, poor diffusion kinetics limit the accessibility of electrochemically active sites, refraining from realizing the theoretical capacity. With increasing demand for highly reliable energy storage devices, higher requirements have been placed on the comprehensive performance of SIBs. For instance, extreme temperature especially low-temperature tolerance has become a principal concern for SIBs due to the sharply reduced diffusion kinetics <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0007" name="bbib0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>. Therefore, expediting the ion/electron transfer kinetics in NVP and further enhancing its specific capacity to promote its practical application is imperative.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0002"><span><span>From a material engineering perspective, doping with <a href="/topics/chemistry/heteroatom" title="Learn more about heteroatoms from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heteroatoms</a> and </span><a href="/topics/engineering/surface-coating" title="Learn more about surface coating from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface coating</a> are the most popular two strategies to improve charge transfer kinetics in NVP. For example, Zhao reported that Al doping in NVP can regulate electronic structure to reduce the bandgap of NVP, resulting in improved electron conductivity </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0008" name="bbib0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>. Chen <em>et al</em>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0009" name="bbib0009" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0009"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a> demonstrated that Zr-doping in NVP (Na<sub>2.9</sub>V<sub>1.9</sub>Zr<sub>0.1</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>) could remarkably facilitate intrinsic electronic conduction for enabling superior rate capability. Kumar Singh <em>et al</em>. reported that by partially replacing V<sup>3+</sup> in NVP with low-valence Mn<sup>2+</sup> and high-valence Mo<sup>6+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0010" name="bbib0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a><span><span><span>, the as-modified NVP exhibits improved rate performance and better <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> because of the facilitated Na-ion </span><a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-kinetics" title="Learn more about diffusion kinetics from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion kinetics</a> from the enlarged </span><a href="/topics/engineering/interstitial-volume" title="Learn more about interstitial volume from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">interstitial volume</a> of NVP lattice. Chen </span><em>et al.</em><span> found that doping an appropriate amount of boron in NVP could effectively lower the energy barrier for Na-ion diffusion and enhance <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a><span> to realize fast and durable <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0011" name="bbib0011" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0011"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a><span>. On the other hand, <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-coating" title="Learn more about surface coating from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface coating</a> as an extrinsic electronic/ionic conductivity enhancement method largely relies on the properties of conductive agents, involving carbon </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0012" name="bbib0012" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0012"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, metal materials <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a><span>, <a href="/topics/engineering/conductive-polymer" title="Learn more about conductive polymer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">conductive polymer</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0014" name="bbib0014" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0014"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a><span><span>, <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxides</a> with high ionic and/or </span><a href="/topics/engineering/electronic-conductivity" title="Learn more about electronic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic conductivity</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0015" name="bbib0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0016" name="bbib0016" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0016"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>], <em>etc</em><span>. Among them, carbon coating is the most popular and economic method as it can effectively improve surface electronic conductivity and <a href="/topics/engineering/buffer-volume" title="Learn more about buffer volume from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">buffer volume</a> changes during Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> extraction and insertion processes. However, the produced carbon <a href="/topics/engineering/layer-coating" title="Learn more about coating layer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coating layer</a><span> is usually <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-material" title="Learn more about amorphous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous</a> and noncontinuous, which cannot guarantee the intergranular electron transportation </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0017" name="bbib0017" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0017"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0019" name="bbib0019" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0019"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0020" name="bbib0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>. Thus, the realization of full potential of active material is largely restricted.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0003"><span><span>Herein, inspired by the synergistic function of steel bars and concrete to afford the <a href="/topics/engineering/reinforced-concrete-structure" title="Learn more about reinforced concrete structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">reinforced concrete structure</a>, we delicately designed a robust interconnected and porous architecture assembled from </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/3d-graphene" title="Learn more about 3D graphene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">3D graphene</a> framework and well-encapsulated Na</span><sub>3.5</sub>V<sub>1.5</sub>Mn<sub>0.5</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span>@C <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a><span> with <a href="/topics/materials-science/hierarchical-porosity" title="Learn more about hierarchical porosity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hierarchical porosity</a><span> (NVMP@C@3DPG) as cathode for SIBs. The graphene framework acts as “rebars”, which can not only mitigate volume change from sodiation/desodiation and ensure structural stability, but also offer 3D <a href="/topics/engineering/electron-pathway" title="Learn more about electron pathways from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron pathways</a> to enable high-efficiency charge transport between active nanobuilding blocks. Simultaneously, NVMP@C particles serve as “concrete” to withstand pressures and support the architecture. Such architecture is in favor of rapid electron/ion transport kinetics for boosting a high-rate capacity and low-temperature performance. Moreover, by substituting 25%  V with Mn atoms, a reversible capacity of 120.5 mAh/g contributed by V</span></span></span><sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup>, Mn<sup>3+</sup>/Mn<sup>2+</sup> and V<sup>5+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/redox-couple" title="Learn more about redox couples from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox couples</a> were attained. Additionally, the discharge mean voltage plateau was obviously increased from ∼3.36 V to ∼3.41 V, which is beneficial for enhancing energy density. As a result, the so-formed reinforced concrete architectures efficiently integrate carbon coated NVMP (concrete) within 3D porous graphene networks (rebars), consequently realizing the combination of electronic conductivity, ionic transport and mechanical strengthen. As expected, such cathode exhibits superior reversible capacity and cycling stability, excellent rate capacity and high tolerance for extreme-temperature operation.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0004"><span>The reinforced concrete-like NVMP@C@3DPG structure, which combines a <a href="/topics/engineering/3d-graphene" title="Learn more about 3D graphene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">3D graphene</a> framework (“rebars”) and Na</span><sub>3.5</sub>V<sub>1.5</sub>Mn<sub>0.5</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span>@C (“concrete”) with <a href="/topics/materials-science/hierarchical-porosity" title="Learn more about hierarchical porosity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hierarchical porosity</a> (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a), was fabricated through a facile polymer/mixed-solvent assisted self-assembly process with a subsequent solid-state reaction (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>b). Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) is an excellent <a href="/topics/chemistry/dispersing-agent" title="Learn more about dispersing agent from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dispersing agent</a><span> due to its amphiphilicity derived from <a href="/topics/engineering/hydrophilicity" title="Learn more about hydrophilic from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrophilic</a><span><span> <a href="/topics/chemistry/carboxamide" title="Learn more about amide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amide</a> groups and hydrophobic alkyl backbone. Furthermore, PVP plays a multi-role as the directing agent for the self-assembly of single-layer </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/graphene-oxide" title="Learn more about graphene oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphene oxide</a><span><span>, the “cement” to encapsulate the precursors of active materials and connect them to the <a href="/topics/materials-science/3d-graphene" title="Learn more about 3D graphene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">3D graphene</a> framework and carbon/nitrogen sources. The mixed solvent was used to construct an internal </span><a href="/topics/engineering/porous-structure" title="Learn more about porous structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous structure</a> based on the formation of a droplet template </span></span></span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>. Similar to the setting process of concrete, NVMP@C@3DPG is obtained after high-temperature annealing.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0001"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-gr1.jpg" height="280" alt="Fig 1" aria-describedby="cap0001"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (473KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (473KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0001"><p id="spara001"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <span>(a) The illustration diagrams of <a href="/topics/chemistry/conduction-electron" title="Learn more about electron conduction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron conduction</a> and Na</span><sup>+</sup> transport, and (b) synthesis process of NVMP@C@3DPG.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0005"><span>NVMP@C@3DPG was firstly characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a> (TEM). The obtained product possesses an interconnected network structure with abundant macro-meso pores interconnected by the 3D graphene framework (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>a and Fig. S1 in Supporting information). Importantly, the so-formed 3D graphene architecture provides the 3D continuous <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/electron-transfer" title="Learn more about electron transfer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron transfer</a><span><span> pathways, and the interconnected <a href="/topics/engineering/porous-structure" title="Learn more about porous structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous structure</a> facilitates rapid electrolyte penetration, favoring </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/electron-transfer" title="Learn more about electron transfer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron transfer</a> and Na</span></span><sup>+</sup> ion diffusion kinetics. In contrast, the control sample (NMVP@PC) without using graphene shows a poorly interconnected porous structure because of the absence of graphene, which is not favorable for electron-ion transfer kinetics (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b). Without graphene and mixed solvent, another control sample (NVMP@C) exhibits bulk structures with a lack of both internal connection and porosity (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>c). Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping reveals <a href="/topics/engineering/homogeneous-distribution" title="Learn more about homogeneous distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">homogeneous distribution</a> of Na, Mn, V, O, and P elements in NVMP@C@3DPG (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0002"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-gr2.jpg" height="469" alt="Fig 2" aria-describedby="cap0002"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0002"><p id="spara002"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>(a–c) SEM images of NVMP@C@3DPG, NVMP@PC and NVMP@C. (d) <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDS</a> mapping of NVMP@C@3DPG. (e) </span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a><span><span><span> image, (f) <a href="/topics/chemistry/tem-image" title="Learn more about HRTEM image from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM image</a> and diffraction spots, and (g) crystal structure of NVMP@C@3DPG. (h) </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> curves of NVMP@C@3DPG, NVMP@PC and NVMP@C. (i) The </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/rietveld-refinement" title="Learn more about Rietveld refinement from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Rietveld refinement</a><span> of <a href="/topics/materials-science/powder-neutron-diffraction" title="Learn more about NPD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">NPD</a><span>, and (j) <a href="/topics/engineering/ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> of NVMP@C@3DPG.</span></span></span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0006"><span>Besides the formed 3D interconnected network structure, the active <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> (NVMP) are well encapsulated inside 3D graphene frameworks (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>e). Using the proposed synthesis strategy, carbon-coated NVMP <a href="/topics/chemistry/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> were </span><em>in-situ</em><span> formed between interconnected graphene interlayers with intimate contact. The as-obtained unique architecture can not only ensure surface electron transport of primary particles, but also boost electron transfer between nanobuilding blocks. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image and the selected area <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a> (SAED) show that the obtained NVMP are single-crystalline with high quality (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>f). The lattice fringes with lattice spacing of 0.62 nm and 0.45 nm were assigned to the (012) and (104) planes of NVP, respectively. These results confirm the successful substitution of Mn<sup>2+</sup> into V sites of NVP (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>g). Moreover, <a href="/topics/engineering/amorphous-carbon" title="Learn more about amorphous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous carbon</a><span> (thickness: ∼5 nm) coated on NVMP and intimately contacted with <a href="/topics/engineering/layer-graphene" title="Learn more about graphene layers from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphene layers</a> was evidently observed, which is beneficial to both the surface and interparticle electron transport (</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>f).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0007">The as-prepared three samples (NVMP@C@3DPG, NMVP@PC and NVMP@C) were examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>h), showing a <a href="/topics/chemistry/purity" title="Learn more about pure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pure</a> phase of Na</span><sub>3.5</sub>V<sub>1.5</sub>Mn<sub>0.5</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a><span><span><span>. The structure of NVMP@C@3DPG was further probed using the <a href="/topics/engineering/joints-structural-components" title="Learn more about joint from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">joint</a> </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/rietveld-refinement" title="Learn more about rietveld refinement from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">rietveld refinement</a> against the </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/powder-neutron-diffraction" title="Learn more about neutron powder diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">neutron powder diffraction</a><span> (NPD) and <a href="/topics/engineering/ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> data, and the refined fit profiles are shown in </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 2</span></span></a><span><span>i and j. The detailed refined structure is summarized in Table S1 (Supporting information). The refined result suggests that Mn and V are located at the octahedral sites (12c) of the crystal structure with the occupation ratio approaching 0.28:0.72 for Mn/V, which is the initial nominal <a href="/topics/chemistry/phase-composition" title="Learn more about composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">composition</a>, and showing agreement with the </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/inductively-coupled-plasma" title="Learn more about inductively coupled plasma from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">inductively coupled plasma</a><span> emission spectrometer (ICP) results, Na:V:Mn:P is 7.1:2.79:0.95:6.0 (Fig. S2 in Supporting information). P atoms are located at the tetrahedral site (18e), while Na1 and Na2 atoms are located at the sites of 6b and 18e, respectively. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/lattice-constant" title="Learn more about lattice parameters from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameters</a> (</span></span><em>a, b</em> = 8.8346(4) Å, <em>c</em> = 21.7135(8) Å and <em>V</em> = 1467.68(12) Å<sup>3</sup>) were found to be larger than those of NVP (<em>V</em> = 1438.73(7) Å<sup>3</sup>) (Table S2 in Supporting information), implying the larger Mn<sup>2+</sup> (0.67 Å) has indeed occupied the V<sup>3+</sup> (0.64 Å) sites. The refined results indicate that Na<sup>+</sup> ions are located within the “lantern” units composed of [V<sub>1.5</sub>Mn<sub>0.5</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>], thus possessing a 3D diffusion pathway (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>g). The X-ray <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about photoelectron spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">photoelectron spectroscopy</a> (XPS) depicts the presence of Mn</span><sup>2+</sup> and V<sup>3+</sup> in the obtained unique hybrid (Fig. S3 in Supporting information) along with the states of carbon and nitrogen, which is beneficial for improving electronic conductivity and electrolyte affinity owing to the introduction of nitrogen into carbon matrix <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0022" name="bbib0022" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0022"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a><span><span>. The highest <a href="/topics/engineering/graphitization" title="Learn more about graphitization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphitization</a> degree of NVMP@C@3DPG was confirmed by </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/raman-spectrum" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> (Fig. S3f in Supporting information). Additionally, the porosity of the samples was characterized by N</span><sub>2</sub><span><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/physisorption" title="Learn more about physisorption from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">physisorption</a><span> (Fig. S3g in Supporting information). The NVMP@C@3DPG exhibits an isotherm of type IV with an H3 <a href="/topics/engineering/hysteresis-loop" title="Learn more about hysteresis loop from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hysteresis loop</a>, suggesting the existence of </span></span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a><span><span>. The <a href="/topics/chemistry/pore-size-distribution" title="Learn more about pore size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore size distribution</a> profile of NVMP@C@3DPG (Fig. S3h in Supporting information) demonstrates a concentrated distribution of mesopores (∼4 and ∼10 nm), and the specific </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/surface-area" title="Learn more about surface area from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface area</a> of NVMP@C@3DPG (20.61 m</span></span><sup>2</sup>/g) is larger than NVMP@PC (18.06 m<sup>2</sup>/g) and NVMP@C (4.41 m<sup>2</sup><span>/g) (Fig. S4 and Table S3 in Supporting information). <a href="/topics/chemistry/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about Thermogravimetric analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Thermogravimetric analysis</a> (TGA) (Fig. S5 in Supporting information) shows that carbon content of NVMP@C, NVMP@PC, and NVMP@C@3DPG is 1.0 wt%, 2.4 wt%, and 6.0 wt%, respectively. Interestingly, by using the same PVP amount, the NVMP@PC exhibits a higher carbon content (2.4 wt%) than that of NVMP@C, suggesting that there is probably an interaction between mixed solvent (ethanol and tetrahydrofuran) and PVP.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0008">The as-prepared various samples were evaluated by galvanostatic charge/discharge measurements (the loading of the active substance is 1.8–2.0 mg/cm<sup>2</sup>). Besides the long voltage plateau at ∼3.4 V, the three NVMP cathodes deliver an extra plateau at ∼3.9 V assigned to the V<sup>5+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/redox-couple" title="Learn more about redox couple from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox couple</a> (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a), indicating the activation of V<sup>5+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup><span> couple by introducing Mn into V sites. Moreover, the mean discharge voltage plateau of NVMP@C@3DPG was elevated by ∼50 mV compared with NVP@C@3DPG (Fig. S6 in Supporting information). NVMP@C@3DPG delivers an initial specific capacity of 120.5 mAh/g at 0.1 C (1 C = 110 mA/g) with the initial <a href="/topics/engineering/coulomb-efficiency" title="Learn more about coulomb efficiency from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coulomb efficiency</a> (ICE) of 91.4%, much higher than those of NVMP@PC (98.1 mAh/g with ICE of 87.5%) and NVMP@C (86.8 mAh/g with ICE of 83.6%), demonstrating the superiority of the fabricated architecture to promote the full release of the intrinsic specific capacity of the active material. Although graphene was used, the volumetric energy density of NVMP@C@3DPG (348.5 Wh/L) is still higher than those of NVMP@C (269.0 Wh/L) and NVMP@PC (302.1 Wh/L), the detailed discussion is given in supporting information). Moreover, NVMP@C@3DPG exhibits a remarkably higher capacity than NVP@C@3DPG (99.6 mAh/g), indicating the positive effect of appropriate Mn-doping in NVP for enhancing sodium storage capacity. The comparison of rate performance displays the superior prominence of NVMP@C@3DPG to NVMP@PC, and NVMP@C (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b). On increasing the current rate from 0.5 C to 15 C, NVMP@C@3DPG exhibits reversible capacities of 115.1, 108.9, 104.1, 96.5, 88.3 and 81.1 mAh/g, respectively, outperforms those of NVMP@PC and NVMP@C. When the current rate returned back to 0.5 C, a reversible capacity of 110.5 mAh/g was well retained, showing excellent reversibility. Even at 20 C, NVMP@C@3DPG still exhibits a capacity of 73.9 mAh/g, 2 or 7 times higher than NVMP@PC (28.0 mAh/g) and NVMP@C (10.7 mAh/g). The related charge-discharge curves of NVMP@C@3DPG are shown in Fig. S7a (Supporting information). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c displays that NVMP@C@3DPG retains 95.6 mAh/g after 500 cycles at 1 C, far higher than those of NVMP@PC (55.8 mAh/g) and NVMP@C (32.0 mAh/g). Furthermore, at 15 C (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d), NVMP@C@3DPG underwent an initial slight capacity decay and then a gradually stable process with a capacity retention of 95.1% (based on the 350<sup>th</sup> cycle). The capacity decay at the initial stage is probably due to the Jahn–Teller effect and Mn dissolution of NVMP <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a><span><span>, then stable cathode <a href="/topics/engineering/electrolyte-interface" title="Learn more about electrolyte interface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrolyte interface</a> (CEI) forms with increasing cycling, thus leading to stable cycling performance. Despite these, NVMP@C@3DPG still delivers a considerable reversible capacity of 88.4 mAh/g after 5000 cycles. To identify the effect of carbon content on </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a>, we also prepare a control sample (NVMP@C@graphene, NMVP@C@G) by using the same graphene and PVP amount without using mixed solvent (Fig. S8 in Supporting information). As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d, NVMP@C@3DPG still exhibits higher specific capacity and better cycling stability. Additionally, NVMP@C@3DPG demonstrated a significantly high reversible capacity of 59.0 mAh/g even after 5000 cycles at 20 C (Fig. S9 in Supporting information). Such finding indicates that the unique 3D interconnected graphene networks and hierarchical porosity are responsible for the significantly increased sodium storage performance.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0003"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-gr3.jpg" height="371" alt="Fig 3" aria-describedby="cap0003"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (620KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (620KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0003"><p id="spara003"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. (a) Charge and discharge curves of NVMP@C, NVMP@PC, NVMP@C@3DPG and NVP@C@3DPG. (b) Rate capability, and (c) cycle performance of NVMP@C, NVMP@PC and NVMP@C@3DPG. (d) Cycle performance of NVMP@C@3DPG and NVMP@C@G (non-mixed organic solvents). (e–g) The <em>ex-situ</em><span> soft X-ray <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/absorption-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about absorption spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">absorption spectroscopy</a> (sXAS) about V and Mn and the related voltage state in NVMP@C@3DPG.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0009"><span>To investigate the redox activity of V and Mn, the X-ray <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/absorption-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about absorption spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">absorption spectroscopy</a> (XAS) of NVMP@C@3DPG was conducted at different charge and discharge states. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e exhibits the XAS at V L<sub>23</sub>-edge and O K-edge. The XAS spectrum at V L<sub>23</sub>-edge is composed of V L<sub>3</sub> and V L<sub>2</sub>-edge at higher energy level due to the spin–orbital coupling of V 2p energy levels. For pristine sample, the XAS spectrum at V L<sub>3</sub>-edge is dominated by peak a<sub>1</sub>, which is located at the comparable energy position at V<sup>3+</sup> in V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> compound. The multiplet features also resemble those observed in V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> compound. This implies that V<sup>3+</sup> is dominant in pristine NVMP@C@3DPG. Upon charging to 3.8 V, the V absorption peaks shifted about 1 eV towards higher energies at both V L<sub>3</sub> and L<sub>2</sub> edges. In the (charge 3.8 V) sample, peak a<sub>2</sub> is dominant, which can be associated with V<sup>4+</sup>, indicating that the valence variation from V<sup>3+</sup> to V<sup>4+</sup><span> upon charging. When further charge to 4.1 V, the variation of the XAS <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/line-spectra" title="Learn more about spectral line from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">spectral line</a> shape at V L</span><sub>23</sub>-edge is not obvious. Note that the absorption peak shift between V<sup>5+</sup> and V<sup>4+</sup> is only ∼0.3 eV <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>. Therefore, it is difficult to distinguish V<sup>5+</sup> from V<sup>4+</sup> L<sub>23</sub><span>-edge <a href="/topics/materials-science/absorption-spectrum" title="Learn more about absorption spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">absorption spectra</a>. When discharged to 2.5 V, XAS at V L</span><sub>23</sub><span>-edge shows the similar <a href="/topics/engineering/spectral-feature" title="Learn more about spectral features from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">spectral features</a> as the pristine sample, indicating the valence variation from V</span><sup>4+</sup> to V<sup>3+</sup>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>e also includes the XAS spectrum at O K-edge, which is composed of the pre-peak region and the high energy region with <a href="/topics/engineering/photon-energy" title="Learn more about photon energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">photon energy</a> above 528 eV. The broad high energy region is due to the transition to the O 2p-transition metal 4sp hybridized states. The pre-peak region can be assigned to the transition between O 1s to the hybridized V 3d-O 2p and Mn 3d-O 1p states. From pristine to charged samples, the intensities of peaks a</span><sub>3</sub> and a<sub>4</sub> are increased, indicating that more empty states appear at the pre-peak regions, corresponding to the loss of electrons at the transition metal sites. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f shows the XAS at Mn L<sub>23</sub>-edge as well. For pristine sample, the peak position and the XAS spectral lineshape are comparable as Mn<sup>2+</sup> where the main absorption peak is denoted as peak b<sub>2</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0025" name="bbib0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>. Upon charge to 3.8 V and 4.1 V, three features have been observed: (1) The shoulder of peak b<sub>2</sub> was identified and peak b<sub>1</sub> disappears; (2) The peak positions of b<sub>2</sub> and b<sub>3</sub> are shifted towards the higher energy region; (3) The intensity ratios between peak b<sub>2</sub> and b<sub>3</sub> increase slightly in the charged samples, suggesting the partial conversion of Mn<sup>2+</sup> to Mn<sup>3+</sup><span>. Based on these findings, it reveals that both V and Mn in NVMP@C@3DPG participate in <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reactions</a>.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0010">To further examine the sodium storage capability of the prepared cathode at a wide temperature range, the three samples were evaluated at −20 °C (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 4</span></span></a><span>a-c) and 50 °C (Fig. S10 in Supporting information). NVMP@C@3DPG exhibits impressive <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> in terms of specific capacity, rate and cycling capabilities at −20 °C, much better than NVMP@PC and NVMP@C. NVMP@C@3DPG delivers a high capacity of 113.5 mAh/g (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>a), much higher than those of NVMP@PC (79.3 mAh/g) and NVMP@C (63.7 mAh/g). Additionally, the <a href="/topics/engineering/coulomb-efficiency" title="Learn more about ICE from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ICE</a> (97.4%) of NVMP@C@3DPG is evidently higher than those of NVMP@PC (84.5%) and NVMP@C (74.5%), also higher than that (91.4%) at 25 °C, indicating a superior Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> intercalation/de-intercalation reversibility at a low temperature condition. Moreover, NVMP@C@3DPG shows a much lower voltage plateau gap (0.15 V) compared to NVMP@PC (0.22 V) and NVMP@C (0.28 V), suggesting a decreased degree of electrochemical polarization. To be noted, the discharge process exhibits two voltage plateaus at ∼3.35 and ∼3.01 V, obviously differentiates from that at <a href="/topics/chemistry/ambient-reaction-temperature" title="Learn more about room temperature from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">room temperature</a> (25 °C). The two-step discharge process is probably attributed to remarkably reduced Na</span><sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics at low temperatures. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b, the rate capability of NVMP@C@3DPG also maintains impressive at −20 °C, with specific capacities of 105.4, 94.6, 78.2 and 36.2 mAh/g at 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 C, respectively. When returned to 0.5 C, NVMP@C@3DPG can still retain a specific capacity of 104.8 mAh/g, corresponding to 99% of the capacity at the initial 0.5 C. The charge–discharge curves of NVMP@C@3DPG at different rates is shown in Fig. S7b (Supporting information). The cycling stability test (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c) shows that NVMP@C@3DPG delivers the highest initial reversible capacity of 89.1 mAh/g at 1 C, 2–3 times higher than that of NVMP@PC (40.0 mAh/g) and NVMP@C (24.9 mAh/g). After 500 cycles at 1 C, the capacity retentions of NVMP@C@3DPG, NVMP@PC, and NVMP@C are 97.1%, 91.0%, and 82.9%, respectively, indicating excellent cycling performance of NVMP@C@3DPG. It could be attributed to the facilitated ion/electron transfer kinetics by the as-designed architecture. Besides low temperature evaluation, NVMP@C@3DPG also exhibits excellent sodium storage at elevated temperature (Fig. S10 in Supporting information). To further explore the application potential of the NVMP@C@3DPG for SIBs, full cells using NVMP@C@3DPG as cathode and hard carbon as anode were constructed (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d). The initial charge-discharge curves of the full cell deliver a reversible capacity of 126.3 mAh/g with a flat plateau of ∼3.35 V and a sloped plateau at ∼3.8 V at 10 mA/g with 90.5% of ICE (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>e). The full cell delivered the specific capacity of 110.3 mAh/g after 80 cycles at 100 mA/g, corresponding to a capacity retention of 89.3% (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>f). Such findings corroborate that the obtained hybrids show a promising potential for practical applications.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0004"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-gr4.jpg" height="252" alt="Fig 4" aria-describedby="cap0004"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (522KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (522KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0004"><p id="spara004"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a–c) Severe temperature performance at −20 °C. (d) Charge–discharge curves for NVMP@C@3DPG and HC. (e) Charge/discharge curves of the full cell at 10 mA/g (1–2 cycles) and 100 mA/g (80 cycles), and (f) cycling at 100 mA/g.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0011"><span><span><span>Furthermore, <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cyclic voltammetry</a> (CV), </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a><span><span> (EIS), and galvanostatic intermittent <a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about titration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">titration</a> technique (GITT) were performed to investigate the kinetics behavior to understand the superior Na-ion storage performance of the obtained NVMP@C@3DPG. Fig. S11 (Supporting information) indicates that NVMP@C@3DPG has the better reaction kinetics, the smaller </span><a href="/topics/engineering/charge-transfer-resistance" title="Learn more about charge transfer resistance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">charge transfer resistance</a>, the higher </span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> (</span><em>D</em><sub>Na<sup>+</sup></sub>), and the higher pseudocapacitive contribution. The cycling stability of the crystal structure of NVMP in NVMP@C@3DPG after 500 cycles at 1 C was investigated by XRD. Based on Figs. S12a–c (Supporting information), the consistency of the XRD curves before and after cycling indicates that NVMP@C@3DPG exhibits excellent crystal stability. Furthermore, it is seen from Fig. S12d (Supporting information) that even after 5000 cycles at 20 C, the 3D interconnected porous architecture of the NVMP@C@3DPG is well maintained, with the atomic ratio of V:Mn consistent with the pristine sample (V:Mn = 3:1) (Figs. S12e and f in Supporting information). EDS mapping identified the uniform element distributions in the sample (Fig. S12g in Supporting information). These results confirm the outstanding structural stability of NVMP@C@3DPG upon repeated Na<sup>+</sup> intercalation and de-intercalation processes.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0012">In summary, a unique reinforced concrete-like hybrid architecture assembled from single-crystalline NVMP nanoparticles and 3D interconnected/porous graphene frameworks has been developed <em>via</em> a facile polymer-assisted self-assembly and subsequent solid-state method. The NVMP@C@3DPG hybrids not only possess 3D interconnected and porous graphene (“rebar”) architectures, but also well immobilize active nanobuilding blocks (“concrete”) inside the above frameworks. The former can provide a high-efficiency electron/ion transportation system and strengthen the structural stability of the whole hybrid while the latter not only affords intimate electronic connection between active building blocks and highly conductive scaffolds, but also facilitates the realization of the full potential of active components. Moreover, the introduction of Mn into V sites cannot only efficiently regulate electron structure and enhance intrinsically electronic conductivity, but also activate the redox couple of V<sup>5+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup><span>, thus showing a higher specific capacity. When employed as cathodes for SIBs, such hybrids exhibit superior high-rate capability and cycling performance at <a href="/topics/chemistry/ambient-reaction-temperature" title="Learn more about room temperature from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">room temperature</a>, low temperature and elevated temperature. Owing to the versatility of transition metal polyanionic compounds, the proposed strategy in this work could be extended to design and optimize other polyanionic compounds with synergistically modulating electronic structures and ion transportation towards energy-related applications.</span></div></div><section id="coi0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0005" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0014">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0006" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgments</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0015">This work was financially supported by the <span id="gs00001">National Natural Science Foundation of China</span> (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs00001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52072119</span></span></a>), <span id="gs00002">Natural Science Foundation</span> of Hunan Province (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs00002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2023JJ50015</span></span></a>), the <span id="gs00003">111 Project</span> (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs00003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">D20015</span></span></a>), and the <span id="gs00004">Australian Research Council</span> (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs00004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">DP230100198</span></span></a>). Part of this work was carried out at the Echidna at the Australian centre for Neutron Scattering under Merit Programs (beamtime: M13623). The authors acknowledge the support of ANSTO staff, especially Prof. Vanessa K. Peterson, for collecting high-resolution NPD data.</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="sec0002"><h2 id="cesectitle9002" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix. Supplementary materials</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0013a"><span class="display"><span class="e-component e-component-mmc1" id="ecom0001"><span class="article-attachment u-margin-xs-bottom"><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1001841723010185-mmc1.docx" target="_blank" download="" title="Download Word document (3MB)"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" width="20" class="icon icon-text-document"><path d="M1 10v108h57.22L91 85.09V10H1m80 70.96L54.07 108H11V20h70v60.96zM43 100h10V80h20V70H43v30M25 32h42v10H25V32zm0 18h42v10H25V50z"></path></svg><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download Word document (3MB)</span></span></span></a></span></span></span></div></section></div></div><div class="related-content-links u-display-none-from-md"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-small" type="button"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Recommended articles</span></span></button></div><div class="Tail"></div><div><section class="bibliography u-font-serif text-s" id="cebibl1"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">References</h2><section class="bibliography-sec" id="cebibsec1"><ol class="references" id="reference-links-cebibsec1"><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bbib0001" id="ref-id-bib0001" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="sbref0001"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">J.Y. Jian, W. Han, X. Lu, <em> et al.</em></div></div><div class="host u-font-sans" id="ref-id-sbref0005">Adv. href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-84876544264&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref0005"><span href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=Z.%20Jian%2C%20W.%20Han%2C%20X.%20Lu%2C%20et%20al.%2C%20Adv.%20Energy%20Mater.%203%20(2013)%20156%E2%80%93160." target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" Chen, Z. Chen, Z. Liu, <em> et al.</em></div></div><div class="host u-font-sans" id="ref-id-sbref0025">Phys. Rev. href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=Z.%20Chen%2C%20Z.%20Chen%2C%20Z.%20Liu%2C%20et%20al.%2C%20Phys.%20Rev.%20Lett.%20119%20(2017)%20156801." target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (5)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1001841724005291"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Spatial confinement of free-standing graphene sponge enables excellent stability of conversion-type Fe&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; anode for sodium storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Chinese Chemical Letters</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara005">Conversion-type anode materials are highly desirable for Na-ion batteries (NIBs) due to their high theoretical capacity. Nevertheless, the active materials undergo severe expansion and pulverization during the sodiation, resulting in inferior cycling stability. Herein, a self-supporting three-dimensional (3D) graphene sponge decorated with Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanocubes (rGO@Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>) is constructed. Specifically, the 3D graphene sponge with resilience and high porosity benefits to accommodate the volume expansion of the Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanocubes and facilitates the rapid electrons/ions transport, enabling spatial confinement to achieve outstanding results. Besides, the free-standing rGO@Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> can be directly used as an electrode without additional binders and conductive additives, which helps to obtain a higher energy density. Based on the total mass of the rGO@Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> material, the rGO@Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> anode presents a specific capacity of 859 mAh/g at 0.1 A/g. It also delivers an impressive cycling performance (327 mAh/g after 2000 cycles at 1 A/g) and a superior rate capacity (162 mAh/g at 20 A/g). The coin-type Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>@C//rGO@Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> NIB exhibits an energy density of 265.3 Wh/kg. This unique 3D ionic/electronic conductive network may provide new strategies to design advanced conversion-type anode materials for high-performance NIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/adfm.202418642" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Enabling One-Step De-Sodiation of Na&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;MnV(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; Cathode via Regulating Coordination Environment for High-Power and Long-Lasting Sodium-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2025, Advanced Functional Materials</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/smll.202410456" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Synergistically Boosted Na&lt;sup&gt;+&lt;/sup&gt; Migration and Deep Desodiation Stability of NASICON Cathode via High Entropy Regulation</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0
